    Calofood

    Calofood.Rmd
    library(Calofood)
library(kableExtra)
library(tibble)

    About the Package

    The Calofood package comprises a dataset containing calorie information from popular fast food restaurants. The dataset is sourced from the Tidytuesday repository available on GitHub. This package provides users with a range of functions. Firstly, it includes a Shiny app which is integrated into the package, enabling interactive interactions with users. This app utilizes the dataset to provide valuable insights to users. Additionally, the package offers a plot function, allowing users to generate bar plots based on their input, leveraging the data within the package. Lastly, there is a numeric function that facilitates annual compound interest calculations using three essential parameters: principal, rate, and time. This feature enhances the package’s versatility by including financial calculations alongside nutritional analysis.

    Why use Calofood package?

    Calofood is a versatile package that empowers users to conveniently access and scrutinize nutritional data from popular fast-food chains. It provides an intuitive interface for obtaining calorie counts and other nutritional specifics for a diverse range of menu items. This package proves valuable for those aiming to maintain a vitamin-rich diet while dining out. Calofood facilitates users in making informed dietary choices by enabling easy access and comparison of nutritional information across various fast-food items available in our package. It equips individuals with the information needed to align with their nutritional goals.

    Data description and Data dictionary

    The dataset was loaded from a file named fastfoodcalories.csv. Initially, the dataset contained 18 variables, but we introduced 10 additional variables through mathematical computations. These extra variables enhance our data analysis capabilities and improve the accuracy of our final food item recommendations.

    The data dictionary in a table format:

    
ffcaldata <- tibble(
  variable = c("...1", "restaurant", "item", "calories", "cal_fat", "total_fat",
               "sat_fat",  "trans_fat", "cholesterol", "sodium", "total_carb", "fiber",
               "sugar", "protein", "vit_a", "vit_c", "calcium", "salad", "carb_percent",
               "protein_percent", "fiber_percent", "vit_a_percent", "vit_c_percent", 
               "calcium_percent", "cholesterol_percent", "sugar_percent",
               "sodium_percent", "sat_fat_percentage"),
  
  class = c("double", "character", "character", "double", "double", "double", "double", 
            "double", "double", "double", "double", "double", "double", "double", 
            "double", "double", "double", "character", "double", "double", "double", 
            "double", "double", "double", "double", "double", "double", "double"),
 
  description = c("Row Index", "Restaurant Name", "Food Item", "Calories", "Calories
                  from Fat", "Total Fat (g)", "Saturated Fat (g)", "Trans Fat (g)",
                  "Cholesterol (mg)", "Sodium (mg)", "Total Carbohydrates (g)",
                  "Dietary Fiber (g)", "Sugars (g)", "Protein (g)", "Vitamin A (% DV)",
                  "VitaminC (% DV)", "Calcium (% DV)", "Salad Type", 
                  "Carbohydrates (% DV)", "Protein (% DV)", "Fiber (% DV)", 
                  "Vitamin A (% DV)", "Vitamin C (% DV)", "Calcium (% DV)",
                  "Cholesterol (% DV)", "Sugars (% DV)", "Sodium (% DV)",
                  "Saturated Fat (% DV)")
)


kbl(ffcaldata, table.attr = 'data-quarto-disable-processing="true"') |>
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE) |>
  column_spec(1, width = "2cm", border_right = TRUE) |>
  column_spec(2, width = "2cm", border_right = TRUE) |>
  column_spec(3, width = "10cm")
    variable class description
    …1 double Row Index
    restaurant character Restaurant Name
    item character Food Item
    calories double Calories
    cal_fat double Calories from Fat
    total_fat double Total Fat (g)
    sat_fat double Saturated Fat (g)
    trans_fat double Trans Fat (g)
    cholesterol double Cholesterol (mg)
    sodium double Sodium (mg)
    total_carb double Total Carbohydrates (g)
    fiber double Dietary Fiber (g)
    sugar double Sugars (g)
    protein double Protein (g)
    vit_a double Vitamin A (% DV)
    vit_c double VitaminC (% DV)
    calcium double Calcium (% DV)
    salad character Salad Type
    carb_percent double Carbohydrates (% DV)
    protein_percent double Protein (% DV)
    fiber_percent double Fiber (% DV)
    vit_a_percent double Vitamin A (% DV)
    vit_c_percent double Vitamin C (% DV)
    calcium_percent double Calcium (% DV)
    cholesterol_percent double Cholesterol (% DV)
    sugar_percent double Sugars (% DV)
    sodium_percent double Sodium (% DV)
    sat_fat_percentage double Saturated Fat (% DV)

    A glimpse at the dataset:

    head(fastfoodcalories)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 28
#>    ...1 restaurant item             calories cal_fat total_fat sat_fat trans_fat
#>   <dbl> <chr>      <chr>               <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1     1 Mcdonalds  Artisan Grilled…      380      60         7       2       0  
#> 2     2 Mcdonalds  Single Bacon Sm…      840     410        45      17       1.5
#> 3     3 Mcdonalds  Double Bacon Sm…     1130     600        67      27       3

#> 5     5 Mcdonalds  Crispy Bacon Sm…      920     410        45      12       0.5
#> 6     6 Mcdonalds  Big Mac               540     250        28      10       1

#> #   fiber <dbl>, sugar <dbl>, protein <dbl>, vit_a <dbl>, vit_c <dbl>,

#> #   calcium_percent <dbl>, cholesterol_percent <dbl>, sugar_percent <dbl>,
#> #   sodium_percent <dbl>, sat_fat_percentage <dbl>

    The functions in the package are as follows:

    • comp_int() - This numeric function computes the annual compound interest.
    • run_app() - This function runs the Shiny app
    • foodplot() - Makes the plots for a vitamin rich diet for food recommendations for different fast food restaurants.

    Using the functions: 

    comp_int(725000, 3, 2)
#> [1] 44152.5
    run_app()
    foodplot("Mcdonalds")
